39.01.text: knowing nothing of the world outside it.

41.61.text: When it was played, the sound would fill their little universe.

45.31.text: They liked the idea that there was

47.01.text: some giant invisible player creating the music.

50.01.text: One day, one of the mice decided to explore the piano.

53.51.text: When he returned, he told the other mice he’d discovered

55.51.text: how the music was really made.

57.51.text: He’d found wires of different lengths

59.61.text: which vibrated to make up the different notes.

62.31.text: Most of the mice began to revise their ideas about their universe,

66.01.text: though a few still believed in the invisible player.

72.51.text: When she returned, she told the other mice she’d discovered

74.81.text: how the music was really made.

76.61.text: She’d found a row of huge hammers,

78.51.text: which struck the wires to make them vibrate.

81.51.text: Most of the mice now felt they had a comprehensive model

86.61.text: And while some still believed in the giant invisible player,

89.51.text: he was generally dismissed as a myth. But the pianist played on."

95.41.text: This was a story sent to me recently,

97.31.text: as an illustration of the futility of scientific enquiry

100.51.text: into the workings of the universe.

102.71.text: I’d already seen it told in various forums,

105.41.text: including a church sermon, a debate about belief,

108.51.text: even a proselytising religious worksheet aimed at school children,

112.01.text: where the pupils were encouraged to validate its message.

117.61.text: there’s a strikingly obvious problem with the story.

120.21.text: But for many theists, it’ll go unnoticed.

123.51.text: I’ll demonstrate the problem later on,

125.31.text: but I dare say when I was a theist myself,

129.71.text: In fact, I can attest to going along with

131.51.text: countless allegorical stories like this, back in the day.

135.31.text: It can be difficult for some atheists

139.71.text: to grasp how allegories like these

141.61.text: could ever have any significant influence over people.

145.01.text: To those atheists, religious allegories are just stories.

149.51.text: But to the theist, they’re much more.

152.01.text: The power of stories has long been recognised.

154.51.text: Stretching back into the earliest human records,

157.31.text: stories have been used to structure ideas, to communicate,

161.61.text: to teach, to galvanise, or simply to entertain.

165.61.text: If we didn’t already suspect it to be the case,

168.01.text: research supports the idea that stories can have

170.31.text: a ‘transporting’ effect on us, which dulls our critical processes

174.71.text: and opens us up to substantial manipulation of our real-word beliefs.

181.31.text: Green and Brock found that subjects who felt more transported by a story —

187.21.text: later identified fewer flaws in the story,

190.01.text: expressed beliefs more consistent with the story,

192.61.text: and gave more favourable evaluations of the story’s protagonists.

197.01.text: Appel and Richter note that when we engage with a story,

200.51.text: we cross over into an imaginary world.

205.31.text: as we begin to experience empathy and identification

208.11.text: with the characters presented to us.

210.21.text: It also affects our cognitive processing.

212.61.text: We’re kind to stories. We play by their rules.

216.31.text: And our responses can become substantially framed

218.61.text: by the standards of the imaginary world,

221.01.text: rather than those of the real world.

222.81.text: If the story is engaging enough to us,

225.01.text: dubious ideas can be smuggled into our belief system

227.61.text: without our awareness, under a blanket of appealing narrative.

231.91.text: Appel and Richter got subjects to read fictional passages

234.81.text: seeded with false information, and found an immediate effect,

238.81.text: with subjects’ attitudes shifting in line with the false information.

242.31.text: But beyond that, they saw a larger delayed effect,

245.01.text: called a sleeper effect, where subjects tested two weeks later

248.61.text: showed even more pronounced changes in their beliefs,

253.61.text: as well as a higher level of certainty in those beliefs.

257.01.text: In many ways, the process being described here

259.31.text: echoes the parasitic breeding of the cuckoo.

262.01.text: The cuckoo lays its egg in the nest

263.61.text: of another bird while it’s not looking.

265.61.text: The host bird will then vigorously defend the egg

268.01.text: as if it was its own, even when the cuckoo chick hatches

271.01.text: and pushes the hosts’ own young out of the nest.

274.61.text: It’s no coincidence that stories are by far

277.31.text: the dominant mode of expression in religion.

279.41.text: The language of faith is not scientific enquiry.

282.61.text: The daily and weekly congregations gather

285.01.text: with no intention of assessing their ideas

287.21.text: against a systematic set of criteria

292.31.text: In fact, those individuals who do cast a critical eye

295.61.text: will soon become the target of an escalating schedule of disapproval.

299.91.text: The language of faith is not logical argument.

302.61.text: Even to this day, if I mentioned any of the deductive offerings

306.01.text: of theologians like Anselm, Augustine and Aquinas,

310.21.text: most — if not all — of the christians in my personal life

313.31.text: wouldn’t have a clue what I was talking about.

324.31.text: Stories told with passion and force.

327.21.text: Heroic narratives. Cautionary tales. Cataclysmic revelations.

332.61.text: As theists, these stories transport us.

335.61.text: And in that transported state, all manner of ideas

338.61.text: can be inserted into our belief systems without resistance.

342.01.text: As atheists, religious stories don’t transport us.

345.81.text: We process the ideas these stories contain in a sober state,

349.81.text: and the flaws often leap out at us.

352.51.text: As theists, we tend not to be transported

355.01.text: by the stories of other religions.

357.01.text: We tend to assess them with detachment ....

359.71.text: although the lines can begin to blur for us

361.81.text: when the stories of other religions stray close to ours

365.11.text: or, conversely, when the stories of our own religion stray too far away.

371.31.text: When I was twelve, and believed in a christian deity called Yahweh,

376.51.text: a christian speaker came to our school to give a talk.

379.71.text: In the Q & A after his main speech, someone asked him about hell.

383.51.text: He smiled and said, ‘Hell isn’t what you think it is.’

387.01.text: It’s perhaps worth noting at this point that

389.01.text: a knowing smile doesn’t actually require knowledge —

394.01.text: He then announced that heaven and hell were in fact exactly the same.

397.51.text: He said that both places were packed with huge long tables,

401.01.text: lined with bowls of amazing stew.

403.61.text: Everyone had their own spoon and was free

406.01.text: to eat as much as they liked,

407.81.text: as the food would never run out.

409.81.text: The only problem was the spoons were twice the length of their arms,

413.61.text: so they couldn’t bring it to their mouths.

416.01.text: And indeed when you looked around hell,

418.31.text: the damned were all starving and emaciated.

421.51.text: But when you looked around heaven,

423.11.text: where the spoons were just as long,

424.81.text: everyone was well fed and healthy.

426.81.text: The speaker then invited the audience to guess why.

429.81.text: Hands shot up, and one boy answered

432.31.text: that the people in heaven fed each other.

434.81.text: Well, it was hardly applied physics, was it.

440.61.text: As a fellow christian, sitting in that audience, I was bemused.

445.01.text: This was categorically not what hell was like.

449.61.text: into which the damned would be thrown on judgement day,

452.41.text: and from which there was no escape.

455.01.text: As I left the talk I wasn’t sure whether

456.81.text: the speaker had committed blasphemy by misrepresenting hell.

460.51.text: But I did know his long spoon story was an incoherent mess.

465.01.text: There seemed to be an implicit assumption in the story

467.21.text: that feeding someone else implied empathy, charity, generosity, love —

473.11.text: and that it was for the lack of these qualities that the folks in hell starved.

477.51.text: But feeding someone else neither implied nor necessitated any of these traits.

482.41.text: Cooperation is observed throughout the natural world.

485.61.text: A remarkable example can be seen among hermit crabs,

488.51.text: who use abandoned shells as a home.

490.61.text: As they grow, they have to find progressively larger shells to contain them.

495.01.text: When a large unused shell washes up on a beach,

497.81.text: hermit crabs of all sizes can be seen to gather round it,

501.31.text: and sort themselves into a cue of ascending size.

504.41.text: They’ll each then move into the next larger shell,

509.21.text: Do they behave this way because they’re aspiring

511.31.text: to some moral or religious virtue? Of course not.

515.21.text: They’ve learned to cooperate because it brings mutual benefit.

518.81.text: Just like we have. Even at the age of twelve,

521.81.text: I knew full well that the most greedy, self-serving individuals

525.91.text: would be among the first to feed each other with those long spoons,

529.61.text: not out of love for their fellow human

532.01.text: but because they recognised what was good for them.

535.21.text: As such, according to the division suggested in the story of the long spoons,

540.01.text: these uncharitable folks would be in heaven, not hell.

544.01.text: The depth of wisdom this story hinted at

546.51.text: was nothing more than a wafer-thin veneer.

549.61.text: The speaker wanted it both ways.

551.71.text: He wanted to present hell as a place beyond reproach;

555.21.text: an unappreciated utopia, overflowing with food enough for everyone.

560.01.text: But at the same time, he needed it be a place of agonising torture.

564.01.text: In order to try and reconcile these irreconcilable extremes,

568.51.text: he was forced to populate hell

573.71.text: and hope the audience was all too swept up to notice.

579.81.text: It was too significant a departure from the fiery pit

583.11.text: in which I’d been coerced to believe.

587.81.text: Members of a school christian group to which I belonged

590.21.text: had been very inspired by the speaker

592.51.text: and readily took on this new definition of hell.

595.61.text: In view of the long-lasting manipulative potential of stories,

599.21.text: Appel and Richter end their paper by proposing that

601.61.text: further research is needed on strategies that people can use

604.51.text: to actively prevent information in fictional narratives

610.31.text: Just knowing about the power of stories

611.91.text: is a good first step toward immunisation.

614.71.text: Another step might be to reconsider

616.51.text: some of the stories we’ve found persuasive,

619.01.text: and think about what exactly they persuaded us of;

622.51.text: perhaps play around with the details,

624.81.text: to highlight the elements we’ve let slip by with noticing.

628.41.text: Which brings us back to the mice and the piano.

653.01.text: One day some of the young mice went exploring inside the piano.

656.41.text: When they returned, they told the old mice

658.51.text: that they’d discovered wires that vibrated

662.51.text: to produce some of the notes in the music.

664.71.text: But this only accounted for one of the sounds they heard.

667.61.text: They suggested that maybe there were

670.81.text: each in charge of a different sound

672.81.text: and all playing together in harmony.

675.31.text: But the old mice scoffed at this preposterous notion.

679.01.text: No. There could only be one invisible player.

681.71.text: To the old mice, it pointed to one conclusion:

684.51.text: their beloved invisible player must simply be even larger,

688.01.text: more complex and more mysterious than they’d ever imagined.

692.01.text: They’d previously conceptualised him as a giant mouse,

694.81.text: but if he was a mouse, he must have hundreds of legs.

699.21.text: he didn’t even have a body, just a mind.

702.21.text: Yes that was it. The music was made

705.01.text: by a single powerful disembodied mind.

711.41.text: So, listening to this story, have you become a polytheist?

716.81.text: After all, if it’s true of mice and pianos, ergo it must be true of life.

721.91.text: From this story, we can see that the universe

724.11.text: is obviously the work of many beings working together.

728.01.text: You wouldn’t want to be like the stubborn old mice

730.21.text: who had to invent some incoherent nonsense

732.51.text: about a disembodied mind, just to preserve their false beliefs.

743.01.text: who lived inside a clockwork piano in an old, abandoned house.

759.51.text: The mice were comforted by the idea

761.31.text: that there was a giant invisible player.

764.01.text: But in fact they were all alone.”

767.31.text: So, after hearing this, who now believes

769.41.text: there was a creator god who set up the universe

772.71.text: but then died before we came along?

775.41.text: No? But the story proves that’s exactly what happened.

782.11.text: Didn’t you comprehend its deeper meaning?

797.21.text: They liked the idea that there was

798.61.text: some giant invisible player creating the music.

823.61.text: You get the point. Like so many other allegories,

826.61.text: what makes the story of the mice and piano worthless

828.81.text: is that you can use it to justify any conceivable religion you like.

832.71.text: Just as circular arguments fallaciously smuggle into their premises

836.11.text: the thing they set out to prove in the conclusion,

838.61.text: circular allegories like the mice and piano

843.11.text: in order to illustrate that deities are self-evident.

848.81.text: which is self-evident from the fact that

850.31.text: members of different religious groups each believe

852.71.text: that their conflicting descriptions of deities are self-evident.

857.11.text: No one knows the entire explanation of the universe.

859.71.text: But so far humankind has managed to piece together some of it.

864.81.text: What lies beyond our knowledge can simply be labelled ‘We don’t know’.

869.01.text: Well that’s the honest and accurate way to label it, isn’t it?

872.81.text: There’s no false claim in that label;

875.01.text: no assumption; no bias; no prejudice.

878.21.text: Nothing that would colour our enquiries.

880.71.text: The same can’t be said when we label the unknown:

895.01.text: or any other of the panorama of deities

897.41.text: humans have proposed over the millennia.

899.41.text: This is no longer open enquiry.

901.61.text: We’re no longer following the evidence

903.21.text: or the argument wherever they lead.

905.11.text: We’re instead leading the evidence and the argument

907.81.text: where we want them to go.

909.81.text: Let’s think for a moment about the sheer perversity of doing this.

913.11.text: Imagine that between you and the answers

915.01.text: to the ultimate nature of the universe lies a maze.

918.31.text: There are trails of evidence in the form of tiny breadcrumbs

921.61.text: which will guide you through the maze.

925.61.text: the breadcrumbs can be detected and followed,

928.01.text: and eventually you will find those ultimate answers.

931.51.text: Now imagine walking through the maze

933.31.text: throwing your own breadcrumbs ahead of you

935.41.text: down a path you’ve already decided to walk.

937.91.text: Because that’s exactly what you’re doing

939.81.text: when you decide in advance the nature of the universe.

943.21.text: And like all those before you who wanted the universe to fit

945.81.text: their preconceived fantasy, rather than get to know it on its own terms,

949.81.text: you are dooming yourself to a dead end.

952.81.text: We don’t know everything about the universe.

955.01.text: But the parts we do know certainly didn’t come from religion,

957.81.text: and the pseudo-wisdom of its stories.

960.01.text: Stories that taught us the sun had one setting place,

963.11.text: and that the stars in the sky were small enough

965.11.text: to fall down on the Earth like figs falling from a shaken fig tree.

969.61.text: to see diseases like leprosy as curses and divine punishments;

974.11.text: to take hallucinations and seizures as signs of demonic possession.

978.21.text: Stories that led to countless thousands of women

980.61.text: being defined as witches possessing nonexistent magical powers —

984.71.text: leading to their torture and murder in the witch hunts.

988.11.text: When we brace ourselves to look with an unflinching eye

991.21.text: at exactly the kind of superstitious swamp

993.31.text: in which we would now be living

994.71.text: if we’d relied on religion as a source of knowledge,

997.21.text: then the true power of stories becomes disturbingly apparent.

1003.31.text: it’s always been through the exploration and observation of our universe;

1007.01.text: by men and women who possessed the drive,

1009.61.text: the discipline and often the courage

1011.91.text: to contradict the supposed wisdom of stories.

1015.71.text: Some atheists describe the stories in the holy books as fairy stories.

1021.51.text: But the comparison is nonetheless worth reflection.

1024.41.text: You don’t come away from fairy stories

1026.01.text: believing in sorcerers, goblins, talking dragons, magic porridge bowls.

1030.61.text: You come away thinking about the choices the characters made.

1035.11.text: in describing human feelings, motivations and behaviour.

1038.31.text: Seeing human or non-human characters in challenging situations

1041.71.text: can give us insight into our own natures and expand our choices.

1046.21.text: But stories cannot be used to prove the existence of supernatural phenomena.

1050.01.text: So if, when you look at your beliefs about reality,

1052.61.text: you do find fairytale notions among them — talking snakes,

1056.11.text: people living for days inside giant fish,

1060.21.text: afterlives full of servants and juicy virgins —

1063.61.text: have a think about how those ideas got planted there.

1066.41.text: Because if you believe in these things, I guarantee you:
